revision.text:
{{infobox artist | name = Albert Paley | image = Albert Paley.jpg | alt = | caption = Paley (left) shows off his studio in 2006 to [[Dana Gioia]] and [[Louise Slaughter]]. | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], United States | alma_mater = [[Temple University]] | known_for = [[Sculpture]] | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = Frances Paley | awards = | website = {{URL|albertpaley.com}} }} [[File:'Push Plate', bronze sculpture by Albert Paley (American born 1944), 1981, Metropolitan Museum of Art.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''Push Plate'', a bronze sculpture by Albert Paley, 1981, [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]]] '''Albert Paley''' (born 1944) is an American modernist metal [[sculptor]]. Initially starting out as a jeweler, Paley has become one of the most distinguished and influential metalsmiths in the world.{{cite book | title = American Metal: The Art of Albert Paley | year = 2014 | publisher = Corcoran Gallery of Art | isbn = 978-0-88675-084-8}} Within each of his works, three foundational elements stay true: the natural environment, the built environment, and the human presence.{{cite book | last = Ratcliff | first = Carter | title = Albert Paley in the 21st Century | year = 2010 | publisher = Memorial Art Gallery of the University of Rochester | isbn = 978-0-615-35392-0 | pages = 19}} Paley is the first metal sculptor to have received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the [[American Institute of Architects]].{{cite web|title=Lecture by Albert Paley|url=http://aiamiami.org/events/lecture-by-albert-paley/|website=AIA Miami|publisher=AIA Miami|accessdate=6 July 2016}}{{cite web|title=Albert Paley|url=http://www.craftinamerica.org/artists/albert-paley/|website=Craft in America|publisher=Craft in America|accessdate=6 July 2016}} He currently lives and works in [[Rochester, New York]] with his wife, Frances. ==Early life and education== He was born in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] during [[World War II]]. While his father fought in the [[Burma Campaign]], Albert and his mother lived with his maternal grandparents.{{cite book | last = Lucie-Smith | first = Edward | title = The Art of Albert Paley: Iron & Bronze & Steel | year = 1996 | publisher = Harry N. Abrams, Incorporated | isbn = 0-8109-3748-4}} Most of Paley’s free-time in his young years became occupied by model-kits and the outdoors. At around age 8, Paley joined the [[Boy Scouts of America]], and even became a face for a billboard for the Boy Scouts. At 16, he dropped out of school with no intention of going to college — he planned to work jobs and support his mother after his father developed [[arthritis]]. It wasn’t until a girlfriend took him to the [[Tyler School of Art]] that Paley found a blossoming passion for the arts.{{cite book | last = Gilbert | first = Lela | title = Reconfiguration | year = 2008 | publisher = Pinatubo Press | isbn = 978-0-9742683-2-3}} After excelling in a first semester at Tyler, Albert was accepted into the selective honors program where he had a free selection of classes. During his second year at Tyler, Paley became interested in jewelry-making. He became a studio assistant in the school’s metal-shop under the supervision of [[Stanley Lechtzin]], who was a strong influence for Paley. Paley earned his [[Bachelor of Fine Arts]] in sculpting with a minor in [[metalsmithing]] in 1966. After receiving his BFA, Paley was torn between sculpting and metalwork for a master's degree, but eventually settled and earned his [[Master of Fine Arts]] in [[goldsmithing]]. Paley taught full-time while a graduate student, and had stopped experimenting in sculpture, focusing all his time and energy into jewelry work. He received both diplomas from the [[Tyler School of Art]], a part of [[Temple University]], in Philadelphia. He moved to [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]], [[New York (state)|New York]] in 1969 to teach at the [[Rochester Institute of Technology]], where he now holds an endowed chair.{{cite web|title=Albert Paley|url=https://artoncampus.rit.edu/artist/112/|website=RIT Libraries Presents art on Campus|publisher=RIT Libraries, Rochester Institute of Technology|accessdate=6 July 2016}} He taught [[goldsmithing]] until 1972, when he decided to focus solely on his own work. ==Career== === Jewelry === After receiving his MFA from the Tyler School of Art, Paley worked with metal as a jewelry designer. He became well known for his style and scale. His jewelry was often big and unique, described by Paley himself for “a certain kind of personality that could carry it...for a strong woman rather than someone who was repressed”.{{cite book |title= Albert Paley: Sculptural Adornment | year= 1991 |publisher= National Museum of American Art, Smithsonian Institution |isbn= 0-295-97152-5}} Despite his movement toward forging iron and away from jewelry in the 70's, Paley still continued to make jewelry during the beginning of his career in metalworking. Much of his jewelry was made for private commissions, keeping the pieces solely between him and his clients. He eventually stopped making jewelry completely, collecting any pieces in the possession of galleries, and selling all his tools. Since 1965, Paley's jewelry and metal work have been in over one hundred and fifty national and international exhibitions.{{cite book | title = The Metalwork of Albert Paley | year = 1980 | publisher = John Michael Kohler Arts Center of the Sheboygan Arts Foundation, Inc. | isbn = 0-932718-06-X}} [[File:Albert_Paley_Renwick_Portal_Gates_for_the_Renwick_Gallery_1994.tif|thumb|right|''Portal Gates'', gate commission for the Renwick Gallery by Albert Paley, 1974, [[Renwick Gallery]]]] === Gates & Functional Objects === During his last year in the Philadelphia area, Paley began experimenting with metal again, specifically forging iron. He and Lechtzin pulled together a small workshop for forging in the garage of Lechtzin’s home, and spent the summer of 1969 reading about forging and learning how to work with different tools. Paley’s big breakthrough was in 1973, when he was awarded a commission from the [[Smithsonian]] to design the portal gates for the [[Renwick Gallery]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] Susan Stamberg (July 22, 2014). [https://www.npr.org/2014/07/22/333596118/with-swirls-of-steel-these-sculptures-mark-the-passage-of-people-and-time With Swirls Of Steel, These Sculptures Mark The Passage Of People And Time] ''[[NPR]]''. In order to build the gates, Paley found a space to rent and filled it with machinery. He hired a past student, Richard Palmer, as a full-time assistant, and they spent a year creating the famous [http://americanart.si.edu/collections/search/artwork/?id=19204 Portal Gates] for the Renwick. After the Portal Gates, Paley’s career in [[metalworking]] took off, with a focus in functional design: tables, lamps, and other usable forms of sculpture. Paley had created an array of decorative objects before the Renwick Gates, using his garage-shop. But after the gates were finished for the Renwick, Paley was left with a much larger work-space, in addition to a full-time assistant, supplies, and machinery. Paley already had another museum commission from the [[Hunter Museum of American Art]] in [[Tennessee]] for an 85-foot long ornamental [http://emuseum.huntermuseum.org/eMuseum/view/objects/asitem/26/78/people-asc?t:state:flow=f1239fdc-9b40-443b-92a9-57605b1bd05a fence].{{cite news |last = Hasden |first = Wes |title = Hunter Museum gets Wrought Iron Fence Sculpture |newspaper = The Chattanooga Times |date= August 29, 1975}} Since then, Paley has done many private commissions for driveway, garden, and fence gates in addition to his numerous public commissions. Some of his gates to note are the Portal Gates for the [[New York State Senate]] Chamber of the State Capitol (1980); the Victoria and Albert Gates for the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]][http://www.vam.ac.uk/](1982); and the Animals Always Gateway Sculpture for the [[St. Louis Zoo]] (2006), currently the largest sculpture at any zoo in the U.S.{{cite web| title= Animals Always Sculpture |url= https://www.stlzoo.org/about/featurednews/animalsalwayssculpture/ |website= Saint Louis Zoo |publisher= Saint Louis Zoo |accessdate= 7 July 2016}}{{cite book| last = Rowe |first= M. Jessica |title= Albert Paley: Portals & Gates |year= 2007 |publisher= University Museums, Iowa State University |isbn= 978-0-9798111-0-4}} === Large-Scale Sculpture === Paley’s first major public sculpture was his Sculpture for the [[Strong Museum]] in 1982. It was his first piece that showed a transition from smaller-scale work to his monumental sizes. Paley did several other large-scale sculptures in the 80’s which share similarities in their simplicity of form with basic elements. Over time, his sculptures have moved away from simple forms, increasing in both complexity and color. In the summer of 2013, Paley was the featured artist on [[Park Avenue]].{{cite book| last= Sims |first= Patterson |title= Albert Paley on Park Avenue |year= 2013 |publisher= Silvana Editoriale, Italy |isbn= 8836627196}} Thirteen sculptures were installed for exhibition between 52nd and 67th Streets in [[New York City]]. This collection of sculptures was one of Paley’s larger projects for one exhibition.{{cite web |title= Summer Exhibition on Park Avenue Features 13 New Steel Sculptures by Albert Paley |url= http://artdaily.com/news/63569/Summer-exhibition-on-Park-Avenue-features-13-new-steel-sculptures-by-Albert-Paley |website= Art Daily |publisher= Art Daily |accessdate= 7 July 2016}} [[Craft in America]] featured Paley as the [http://interactive.wxxi.org/paleynyc final Forge artist in Season 5], aired on [[PBS]].{{cite web |title= Paley on Park Avenue: New York City |url= http://interactive.wxxi.org/paleynyc |website= WXXI |publisher= WXXI Public Broadcasting Council |accessdate= 7 July 2016}} Paley's career move from Goldsmith to Metal Sculptor is well explained in an interesting interview by Cathleen McCarthy.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thejewelryloupe.com/albert-paley-bodily-ornamentation/ |title=Albert Paley: Bodily Ornamentation |last=McCarthy |first=Cathleen|date=2010-07-22|website=The Jewelry Loupe|accessdate=2018-04-08}} === Glass & Steel === In 1998, Paley was invited to the [[Pilchuck Glass School]][http://www.pilchuck.com/] for a summer residency. While there, Paley created a mass of glass elements that would be used in later sculptures in [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]]. Paley did another glass residency in 2014 with the [[Corning Museum of Glass]][http://www.cmog.org/] located in [[Corning, New York]]. He worked there for a year, where he practiced furnace-working and cast Corning Code 7056, a specific type of [[glass]] that can form bonds with a metal alloy called [[Kovar]].{{cite magazine |last= Hopman |first= Rebecca |year= 2015 |title= A New Endeavor: The Corning Museum of Glass/Corning Incorporated Specialty Glass Residency |url= http://rebeccahopman.com/index/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/GAS-Sum15.pdf |magazine= GASNEWS |publisher= Corning Museum of Glass |volume= 26 |issue= 2 |pages= 12–13}} Paley chose this specific glass blend because of its similar properties to that of Kovar, which allowed him to create pieces that fused the glass and metal with each other.{{cite web |title= Biography: Albert Paley |url= http://www.cmog.org/bio/albert-paley |website= Corning Museum of Glass |publisher= Corning Museum of Glass |accessdate= 7 July 2016}}{{cite web| last= Borgna | first= Stephen |title= Artist Q&A: Albert Paley mixes metal, glass |url= http://www.the-leader.com/news/20160327/artist-qa-albert-paley-mixes-metal-glass |website= The Leader |publisher= The Leader |accessdate= 7 July 2016 }} The first exhibition to focus on Paley’s combining of glass and steel, ''Complementary Contrasts: The Glass and Steel Sculptures of Albert Paley'' at Museum of Glass will take place during the 2017 - 2018 season, and will display a collection of pieces spanning Paley's work with glass.{{cite magazine |title= Complementary Contrasts: The Glass and Steel Sculptures of Albert Paley |url= http://museumofglass.org/document.doc?id=405 |publisher= Museum of Glass, Tacoma, WA}} === Major Architectural Commissions === Listed below are some of Albert Paley's major architectural commissions during his career. * 2013: [[Park Avenue]] Sculpture [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wvoK2tOhvlI Series] * 2009: [http://www.theclaycenter.org/ Clay Center] for the Arts and Sciences, [[Charleston, West Virginia]]. entrance sculpture * 2006: [[St. Louis Zoological Park]], St. Louis, Missouri. Animals Always Sculpture, exterior plaza sculpture * 2003: [[Rochester Institute of Technology]], Rochester, New York. Sentinel exterior sculpture * 2000: [[Naples Museum of Art]], Naples, Florida. Portal Gates * 1996: [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]], Culver Studios, Culver City, California. Primordial Reflections, exterior sculpture * 1990: [[Birmingham Museum of Art]], [[Birmingham, Alabama]]. Confluence, exterior sculpture * 1987: [[Wortham Theater Center|Wortham Center for the Performing Arts]], [[Houston, Texas]]. Eight stairway sculptures * 1981: Pennsylvania Avenue Redevelopment Corporation, Washington, D.C. Tree Grates & Benches for [[Pennsylvania Avenue]] * 1974: Smithsonian Institution, [[Renwick Gallery]], National Museum of American Art, Washington, D.C.[http://americanart.si.edu/collections/search/artwork/?id=19204 Portal Gates] == Awards == * 2010: American Craft Council Gold Medal Award for consummate craftsmanship{{cite web|title=Albert Paley |url=https://www.craftcouncil.org/artist/albert-paley |website=American Craft Council |accessdate=12 July 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023021053/http://www.craftcouncil.org/artist/albert-paley |archivedate=23 October 2013 }} * 1998: received the Artist of the Year Award of the Arts & Cultural Council for Greater Rochester.{{cite web|url=http://www.artsrochester.org/AAL/PastHonorees.htm|title=Arts Awards Recipients|publisher=Arts and Cultural Council for Greater Rochester|accessdate= March 19, 2010}} * 1997: Smithsonian Institution, Masters of the Medium Award, Washington, D.C.{{cite web | title= Masters of Medium | url= https://www.jra.org/master-medium | website= James Renwick Alliance | accessdate= 12 July 2016 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304133031/https://www.jra.org/master-medium | archive-date= 4 March 2016 | dead-url= yes | df= dmy-all }} * 1995: American Institute of Architects (AIA), Institute Honors Recipient, Lifetime Achievement Award
National Association of Schools of Art and Design, Citation for Distinguished Service in the Visual Arts * 1994: [[American Craft Council]], Inducted to the College of Fellows{{cite web|title=American Craft Council College of Fellows |url=https://www.craftcouncil.org/content/awards/american-craft-council-college-of-fellows |website=American Craft Council |accessdate=12 July 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140124033426/http://www.craftcouncil.org/content/awards/american-craft-council-college-of-fellows |archivedate=24 January 2014 }} * 1982: American Institute of Architects (AIA), Award of Excellence ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Bibliography== * Kuspit, Donald Burton (2006). ''Albert Paley, Sculpture''. Milan, Italy: Skira. * Lucie-Smith, Edward (1996). ''The Art of Albert Paley, Iron, Bronze, Steel''. New York: H.N. Abrams. * Norton, Deborah L. (1991) ''Albert Paley, Sculptural Adornment''. Washington, D.C.: [[Renwick Gallery|Renwick Gallery of the National Museum of American Art]], [[Smithsonian Institution]] in association with the [[University of Washington Press]]. ==External links== * {{URL|albertpaley.com}}, his official website * [http://interactive.wxxi.org/paleynyc WXXI, Rochester"s PBS station page for the web series Paley on Park Avenue 2013] * [http://renwick.americanart.si.edu/ The Renwick Gallery] * Wortham Center for the Arts [http://www.houstonfirsttheaters.com/Wortham-Center official website] {{clear}} ==See also== {{portal|Biography|Visual arts}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Stanley Lechtzin]] * [[Martin Blank (artist)|Martin Blank]] * [[Site-specific art]] * [[Jack E. Anderson]] * [[List of American artists 1900 and after]] * [[List of people from Rochester, New York]] * [[List of sculptors]] * [[List of Temple University people]] * [[Visual art of the United States]] * [[Walenty Pytel]] {{div col end}} {{clear}} {{American Craft Council}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Paley, Albert}} [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:20th-century American educators]] [[Category:20th-century American sculptors]] [[Category:21st-century American people]] [[Category:21st-century American sculptors]] [[Category:American male sculptors]] [[Category:American contemporary artists]] [[Category:American goldsmiths]] [[Category:Art educators]] [[Category:Sculptors from New York (state)]] [[Category:Artists from Philadelphia]] [[Category:Educators from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Rochester Institute of Technology faculty]] [[Category:Saint Louis Zoo people]] [[Category:Temple University alumni]] [[Category:Sculptors from Pennsylvania]]

page.title: Charles B. Rangel International Affairs Fellowship

revision.comment: Added an additional undergraduate institution (the University of Illinois at Chicago) to the section "Undergraduate institutions that have had students selected for the program include".
revision.text:
The '''Charles B. Rangel International Affairs Fellowship Program''' is a [[Scholarship|fellowship]] program that provides funding for [[graduate student]]s as they prepare academically and professionally to enter the [[United States Foreign Service]].
==History== Launched to help promote greater diversity in the U.S. Foreign Service, the Rangel Fellowship Program was announced in 2002 by [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Colin Powell]], Congressman [[Charles B. Rangel]], and the President of [[Howard University]], [[H. Patrick Swygert]].<ref name="About Us">{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.rangelprogram.org/index.cfm?session.areaid=2&contentid=701&typeid=CBRIAP92223|publisher=[[Howard University]]|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> In the early years of the program, the [[U.S. Congress]] provided an appropriation for the program, and its early operations were supported by the Department of State and contributions by the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation]] and the [[Una Chapman Cox Foundation]].<ref name="About Us"/>
==Program components== The program is managed by the [[Ralph J. Bunche International Affairs Center]] at Howard University and is funded by a grant from the [[U.S. Department of State]].
The Rangel Program offers thirty graduate fellowships annually to outstanding seniors and college graduates who want to join the U.S. Foreign Service.<ref name="About Us"/><ref name="Program">{{cite web|title=Graduate Fellowship Program - Program Elements|url=http://www.rangelprogram.org/index.cfm?areaid=2&contentid=673&mcontent=y&typeid=CBRIAP92223|publisher=[[Howard University]]|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> The fellowships help finance two-year graduate programs and provide two paid summer internship opportunities, one on [[Capitol Hill]] and the second at a [[List of diplomatic missions of the United States|U.S. embassy]].<ref name="Program"/>
Like the [[Thomas R. Pickering Fellowship|Thomas R. Pickering Fellowship Program]], the Rangel Fellowship Program guarantees a five-year contract in the Foreign Service to successful Fellows.<ref name="Program"/> Rangel Fellows also receive mentoring from [[Foreign Service Officers]] throughout the duration of the program.<ref name="Program"/>
Undergraduate institutions that have had students selected for the program include the [[University of Illinois]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Evensen|first=Dave|title=Aspiring diplomat earns prestigious internship in international affairs|url=https://illinois.edu/blog/view/6231/157107|publisher=[[University of Illinois]]|date=April 16, 2015|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> the [[University of Illinois at Chicago]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Flood|first=Brian|title=State Dept. honor turns student's 'dream into a reality'|url=https://today.uic.edu/state-dept-honor-turns-students-dream-into-a-reality|publisher=[[University of Illinois at Chicago]]|date=December 6, 2017|accessdate=November 8, 2018}}</ref>[[Fairfield University]],<ref>{{cite web|title=2014 Graduate Eric Salgado Awarded Prestigious Rangel Fellowship|url=http://news.fairfield.edu/topstories/topstoryheadline,99019,en.html|publisher=[[Fairfield University]]|date=May 15, 2015|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[University of Missouri]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Murray|first=John|title=Past MSA President Earns Prestigious Rangel Fellowship|url=http://fellowships.missouri.edu/news/2013/xavier_billingsley.php|publisher=[[University of Missouri]]|date=April 2, 2013|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[Princeton University]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Dienst|first=Karin|title=Princeton senior receives Rangel Fellowship in international affairs|url=https://www.princeton.edu/main/news/archive/S39/58/50M17/index.xml?section=topstories|publisher=[[Princeton University]]|date=March 26, 2014|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[Paine College]],<ref>{{cite web|title= Paine College senior awarded prestigious Rangel Fellowship|url=http://www.paine.edu/press.aspx?art=163|publisher=[[Paine College]]|date=May 4, 2009|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[Baruch College]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Baruch Alumna Receives Rangel Fellowship for Graduate Work in International Affairs|url=http://www.baruch.cuny.edu/news/andreea_ursu_rangel_fellow_08.htm|publisher=[[Baruch College]]|date=April 16, 2008|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Vivian Ekey ’11 Chosen as Rangel Fellow|url=http://news.umbc.edu/vivial-ekey-11-chosen-as-rangel-fellow/|publisher=[[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]]|date=April 2, 2013|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[Lincoln University (Pennsylvania)|Lincoln University]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Lincoln University senior earns prestigious Rangel Fellowship|url=http://www.phillytrib.com/news/lincoln-university-senior-earns-prestigious-rangel-fellowship/article_b465cc7c-cc43-5bb8-bc83-3c57198e971f.html|work=[[Philadelphia Tribune]]|date=April 23, 2015|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[University of Houston]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Emery|first=Mike|title=UH's Cassie Gianni Named Rangel Fellow|url=http://www.uh.edu/news-events/stories/2015/April/0402Rangel.php|publisher=[[University of Houston]]|date=April 2, 2015|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[Oklahoma City University]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Schwab|first=Kyle|title=Oklahoma City University alumna awarded Rangel Fellowship|url=http://newsok.com/article/4869395|work=[[The Oklahoman]]|date=May 31, 2014|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[University of Georgia]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Walls|first=Joelle|title=UGA Honors student is first recipient of Charles B. Rangel Graduate Fellowship|url=http://news.uga.edu/releases/article/first-recipient-of-charles-b.-rangel-graduate-fellowship/|publisher=[[University of Georgia]]|date=April 5, 2011|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[Ohio State University]],<ref>{{cite web|title=The Ohio State University Alumnus Joshua Gonzalez Wins Prestigious Rangel Fellowship|url=https://internationalstudies.osu.edu/news/swm/au15/rangel|publisher=[[Ohio State University]]|date=Fall 2015|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Alumni Earn Rangel Fellowships|url=http://global.unc.edu/news/ryan-caldwell-and-john-houston-earn-prestigious-rangel-fellowship/|date=April 24, 2013|accessdate=March 24, 2016|publisher=[[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]}}</ref> [[University of Maryland]],<ref>{{cite web|title=UMD Alumnus Cameron Torreon Earns Rangel Fellowship|url=https://sllc.umd.edu/news/umd-alumnus-cameron-torreon-earns-rangel-fellowship|publisher=[[University of Maryland]]|date=March 12, 2012|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[University of Central Florida]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Fellowship Prepares UCF Student for Life Around the World|url=http://today.ucf.edu/topic/charles-b-rangel-graduate-fellowship/|publisher=[[University of Central Florida]]|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[University of South Florida]],<ref>{{cite web|title=CAS alumna receives Charles B. Rangel International Affairs Graduate Fellowship|url=http://www.cas.usf.edu/news/s/679|publisher=[[University of South Florida]]|date=March 18, 2015|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[Middle Tennessee State University]],<ref>{{cite web|title=MTSU alumnus Pratt earns Rangel Fellowship, heads to GWU|url=http://www.mtsunews.com/pratt-rangel-fellowship/|publisher=[[Middle Tennessee State University]]|date=March 29, 2013|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> [[Connecticut College]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Pablo Tutillo ’13 earns prestigious Rangel Graduate Fellowship|url=https://www.conncoll.edu/news/news-archive/2015/pablo-tutillo-13-earns-prestigious-rangel-graduate-fellowship.html|publisher=[[Connecticut College]]|date=June 19, 2015|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref> and [[Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Alumnus Calvin Lee Hayes Earns Prestigious Rangel Fellowship|url=http://www.famu.edu/index.cfm?a=headlines&p=display&news=2372|publisher=[[Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University]]|date=April 15, 2011|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Graduate Fellowship Program - Rangel Fellows In The News|url=http://rangelprogram.org/index.cfm?areaid=2&contentid=679&mcontent=y&typeid=CBRIAP92223|publisher=[[Howard University]]|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref>
Rangel Fellows attend a variety of graduate schools across the United States, including the [[Harvard Kennedy School]], the [[Woodrow Wilson School]], the [[Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy]], the [[Lyndon B. Johnson School]], the [[Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service]], the [[Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies]], the [[School of International Service]], the [[School of International and Public Affairs]], and the [[Elliott School of International Affairs]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Graduate Fellowship Program - Rangel Fellows|url=http://rangelprogram.org/index.cfm?areaid=2&contentid=680&mcontent=y&typeid=CBRIAP92223|publisher=[[Howard University]]|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Thomas R. Pickering Foreign Affairs Fellowship]] *[[United States Foreign Service]] *[[Foreign Service Officer]] *[[African Americans in foreign policy]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.rangelprogram.org/ Official website] *[http://careers.state.gov/work/foreign-service/officer U.S. Department of State Foreign Service Officer]

revision.text:
'''Deep dyslexia ''' is a form of [[dyslexia]] that disrupts [[Reading (process)|reading processes]]. Deep dyslexia may occur as a result of a [[head injury]], [[stroke]], [[Neurological disorder|disease]], or [[Neurosurgery|operation]].<ref name=Harley>{{cite book| last=Harley| first=Trevor A.| title=The psychology of language: from data to theory| publisher=Taylor & Francis| year=2001| pages=189–195| isbn=978-0-86377-867-4 |oclc = 469913878 }}</ref> This injury results in the occurrence of [[Semantics|semantic]] errors during reading and the impairment of nonword reading.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Buchanan">{{cite journal|last=Buchanan|first=Lori|author2=McEwen, Shannon |author3=Westbury, Chris |author4= Libben, Gary |title=Semantics and semantic errors: Implicit access to semantic information from words and nonwords in deep dyslexia|journal=Brain and Language|year=2003|volume=84|issue=1|pages=65–83|doi=10.1016/S0093-934X(02)00521-7}}<!--|accessdate=19 March 2013--></ref>
The term [[dyslexia]] comes from the [[Greek language|Greek]] words 'dys' meaning 'impaired', and 'lexis' meaning 'word' and is used to describe disorders of language concerning reading and [[spelling]].
Numerous models and hypotheses have been proposed in attempt to explain the broad range of symptoms experienced by deep dyslexics, but a definite consensus has yet to be reached. The proposed models and hypotheses have helped in treatment of some suffering patients, but only with certain specific symptoms. Additionally, the recovery seen is not experienced equally in all patients.
==Classification== [[File:Brain trauma CT.jpg|thumb|[[Computerized tomography]] (CT) scan showing brain multiple [[frontal lobe|frontal]], [[parietal lobe|parietal]], and [[temporal lobe]] lesions.<ref name="Rehman08">{{cite journal |vauthors=Rehman T, Ali R, Tawil I, Yonas H |title=Rapid progression of traumatic bifrontal contusions to transtentorial herniation: A case report |journal=Cases Journal |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=203 |year=2008 |pmid=18831756 |pmc=2566562 |doi=10.1186/1757-1626-1-203 |url= http://www.casesjournal.com/content/1/1/203}}</ref> The cause of deep dyslexia is damage in the left hemisphere of the brain]]
Deep dyslexia is usually classified as an ''acquired reading disorder'', as opposed to a ''developmental dyslexia'', in previously literate adults as a consequence of a [[brain injury]].<ref name= "Colangelo">{{cite journal|last=Colangelo|first=Annette|author2=Buchanan, Lori|title=Localizing damage in the functional architecture: The distinction between implicit and explicit processing in deep dyslexia|journal=Journal of Neurolinguistics|year=2007|volume=20|issue=2|pages=111–144|doi=10.1016/j.jneuroling.2006.08.001}}<!--|accessdate=17 March 2013--></ref><ref name= "Colangelokaren">{{cite journal|last=Colangelo|first=Annette|author2=Buchanan, Lori|title=Implicit and explicit processing in deep dyslexia: Semantic blocking as a test for failure of inhibition in the phonological output lexicon|journal=Brain and Language|year=2006|volume=99|issue=3|pages=258–271|doi=10.1016/j.bandl.2005.07.048}}</ref><ref name= "Temple">{{cite journal|last=Temple|first=CM|title=Developmental and acquired dyslexias.|journal=Cortex|year=2006|volume=42|issue=6|pages=898–910|pmid=17131596|doi=10.1016/S0010-9452(08)70434-9}}</ref><ref name= "Coslett">{{cite journal|last=Coslett|first=HB|title=Acquired dyslexia.|journal=Seminars in neurology|year=2000|volume=20|issue=4|pages=419–26|pmid=11149697|doi=10.1055/s-2000-13174}}</ref> However, recently, developmental deep dyslexia has also been reported in children with [[Williams syndrome]].<ref name= "Temple" /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Johnston|first=RS|title=Developmental deep dyslexia?|journal=Cortex|year=1983|volume=19|issue=1|pages=133–9|pmid=6851588|doi=10.1016/s0010-9452(83)80057-4}}</ref>
Deep dyslexia is considered to be a "[[central dyslexia]]" as compared to a "[[peripheral dyslexia]]". Peripheral dyslexics have difficulty matching the visual characteristics of letters that comprise a word to a stored memory of this word from prior encounters.<ref name= "Coslett" /> Central dyslexics are unable to properly match the visual word to the word's meaning.<ref name= "Coslett" /> They may also be incapable of speaking, or [[Phonation|phonating]], the sequence of written letters that they see into the word these letters represent.<ref name= "Coslett" /> Deep dyslexia differs from other forms of central dyslexia ([[phonological dyslexia]] and [[surface dyslexia]]) in that deep dyslexics have many more symptoms and these symptoms are generally more severe.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Rapcsak">{{cite journal|last=Rapcsak|first=Steven Z.|author2=Beeson, Pélagie M. |author3=Henry, Maya L. |author4=Leyden, Anne |author5=Kim, Esther |author6=Rising, Kindle |author7=Andersen, Sarah |author8= Cho, HyeSuk |title=Phonological dyslexia and dysgraphia: Cognitive mechanisms and neural substrates|journal=Cortex|year=2009|volume=45|issue=5|pages=575–591|doi=10.1016/j.cortex.2008.04.006 |pmid=18625494 |pmc=2689874}}</ref><ref name= "Orden">{{cite journal|last=Van Orden|first=G|title=What do double dissociations prove?|journal=Cognitive Science|year=2001|volume=25|issue=1|pages=111–172|doi=10.1016/S0364-0213(00)00036-7}}</ref> According to the "continuum" hypothesis, deep dyslexia is a more severe form of phonological dyslexia.<ref name= "Rapcsak" /><ref name= "Orden" /><ref name= "Lambon">{{cite journal|last=Lambon Ralph|first=Matthew A.|author2=Graham, Naida L.|title=Acquired phonological and deep dyslexia|journal=Neurocase|year=2000|volume=6|issue=2|pages=141–178|doi=10.1080/13554790008402767}}</ref>
==Signs and symptoms==
Deep dyslexia is mainly characterized by the occurrence of [[Semantics|semantic]] reading errors or semantic [[paralexias]] (transposition of letters or words) when reading aloud (e.g. the written word "view" is read aloud as "scene", the word "bird" is read as "canary").<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Plaut">{{cite journal|last=Plaut|first=David C.|author2=Shallice, Tim|title=Deep dyslexia: A case study of connectionist neuropsychology|journal=Cognitive Neuropsychology|year=1993|volume=10|issue=5|pages=377–500|doi=10.1080/02643299308253469}}</ref><ref name= "Weekes">{{cite journal|last=Weekes|first=Brendan|author2=Coltheart, Max |author3=Gordon, Evian |title=Deep dyslexia and right hemisphere reading-a regional cerebral blood flow study|journal=Aphasiology|year=1997|volume=11|issue=12|pages=1139–1158|doi=10.1080/02687039708249437}}</ref> These semantic errors are the major distinguishing feature of deep dyslexia in comparison to other central dyslexias.<ref name= "Coslett" /> There are many other symptoms of deep dyslexia, including visual errors (e.g. the written word "thing" is read aloud as "think", the word "skate" is read as "scale") and derivational errors (e.g. the written word "alcohol" is read aloud as "alcoholic", the word "governor" is read as "government"), and poor reading of [[function word]]s.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Plaut" /><ref name= "Weekes" /> Additionally, deep dyslexics have more difficulty reading [[Abstract and concrete|abstract]] than [[Abstract and concrete|concrete]] and highly imaginable words, more difficulty reading [[adjective]]s, [[adverb]]s, and [[verb]]s than [[noun]]s, a complete inability to read [[Pseudoword|non-words]], and often impairments on tasks of verbal [[working memory]].<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Plaut" /><ref name= "Weekes" /><ref name= "Harley book">{{cite book|last=Harley|first=Trevor|title=The psychology of language : from data to theory|year=2005|publisher=Psychology Press|location=Hove|isbn=978-0-86377-867-4|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Kolb|first=Bryan|title=Fundamentals of human neuropsychology|year=2008|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=Basingstoke|isbn=0-7167-9586-8|edition=6th|author2=Whishaw, Ian Q.}}</ref>
While the symptoms of deep dyslexia listed above are different and independent impairments of reading, it is rare to find an individual who only displays some of the characteristics of it; indeed, most patients presenting with semantic paralexias, a hallmark symptom of the disorder, also demonstrate all of the other symptoms.<ref name= "Weekes" /><ref name= "Coltheartmax">{{cite book|last=Coltheart|first=Edited by Max|title=*Deep dyslexia.|year=1980|publisher=Routhledge & Kegan Paul|location=London|isbn=0-7100-0456-7|edition=[1st publ.].|author2=Patterson, Karalyn |author3=Marshall, John C. }}</ref> This has resulted in deep dyslexia being considered a symptom-complex and has led to much research into why this variety of symptoms may co-occur in so many patients.<ref name= "Weekes" /><ref name= "Coltheartmax" />
===Imageability effect and ease of predication===
The difficulty of deep dyslexics in reading abstract words has been referred to as the "[[imageability]] effect".<ref name= "Temple" /><ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Jones">{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=GV|title=Deep dyslexia, imageability, and ease of predication.|journal=Brain and Language|year=1985|volume=24|issue=1|pages=1–19|pmid=3971130|doi=10.1016/0093-934x(85)90094-x}}</ref><ref name= "Riley">{{cite journal|last=Riley|first=EA|author2=Thompson, CK|title=Semantic Typicality Effects in Acquired Dyslexia: Evidence for Semantic Impairment in Deep Dyslexia.|journal=Aphasiology|year=2010|volume=24|issue=6–8|pages=802–813|pmid=20657815|doi=10.1080/02687030903422486|pmc=2907924}}</ref> According to this idea, the ease with which a [[mental image]] can be created for a word is strongly related to the ease of reading the word.<ref name= "Jones" /> In an attempt to explain this relationship, researchers have developed a variable to link the mental imagery created by a word and the ease of reading it.<ref name= "Jones" /> This variable, [[ease of predication]], is a rating of how easy it is to come up with simple factual statements or attributes of a word.<ref name= "Jones" /><ref name= "Harley2">{{cite journal|last=Harley|first=Trevor A.|title=Connectionist approaches to language disorders|journal=Aphasiology|year=1993|volume=7|issue=3|pages=221–249|doi=10.1080/02687039308249508}}</ref> For example, when presented with the word "dog", an individual may come up with statements, or [[Predicate (grammar)|predicates]], such as "has four legs", "is an animal", or "barks and wags its tail". Words with higher ease of predication scores are more easily read aloud by deep dyslexics than words with lower ease of predicaton scores, yet there is no correlation between ease of predication and ease of reading seen in normal adult readers.<ref name= "Jones" /><ref name= "Harley2" /> Ease of predication may not explain specific symptoms of deep dyslexia, but rather indicates that deep dyslexics read using imagery, or a predicational route, rather than the more precise mechanisms used in normal reading.<ref name= "Jones" />
==Mechanism==
There are many different, and often conflicting, hypotheses that attempt to explain the deficits associated with deep dyslexia.<ref name= "Shallice">{{cite book|last=Shallice|first=Tim|title=From neuropsychology to mental structure|year=1988|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge [England]|isbn=0521308747|edition=Reprint.}}</ref> These theories have resulted in several models designed to conceptualize the symptom-complex found in deep dyslexics. These models are not ordered chronologically, but rather follow a general increasing trend of presence in the field of knowledge regarding deep dyslexics. Some models may be stronger than others, but that is not necessarily reflected here. Models and hypothesis toward the end of the list are more heavily debated and thus typically have a greater wealth of knowledge surrounding their topic.<ref name = "Colangelo" />
===Continuum model===
The "Glosser and Friedman (continuum) model" is based upon the concept that deep dyslexia and phonological dyslexia are opposite endpoints on a "continuum" of reading disability.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Friedman">{{cite journal|last=Friedman|first=Rhonda B.|title=Recovery from Deep Alexia to Phonological Alexia: Points on a Continuum|journal=Brain and Language|year=1996|volume=52|issue=1|pages=114–128|doi=10.1006/brln.1996.0006}}<!--|accessdate=18 March 2013--></ref> Deep dyslexia appears to be a more severe form of phonological dyslexia;<ref name= "Rapcsak" /><ref name= "Orden" /><ref name= "Lambon" /> however, symptoms in patients can change over time so that an initial diagnosis of deep dyslexia is later better described as strictly a phonological dyslexia.<ref name= "Colangelo" /> These observations suggest recovery is possible along the [[semantic pathway]].<ref name= "Colangelo" />
Friedman justifies the continuum hypothesis with two sets of evidence. The first involves five patients who started with deep dyslexia, but whose disorders shifted to phonological dyslexia during recovery. Semantic paralexias were the first symptom to diminish, either partially or totally, in each case and then other symptoms were resolved to varying degrees after that. However, nonword reading was always the last symptom to go and complete recovery was never reached by any patient.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Crisp|first=J.|last2=Ralph|first2=M.A.|date=|year=2006|others=|title=Unlocking the Nature of the Phonological-Deep Dyslexia Continuum: The Keys to Reading Aloud Are in Phonology and Semantics|url=|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|volume=18|issue=3|pages=348–362|doi=10.1162/089892906775990543|pmid=16513001|access-date=}}</ref>
Her second set of evidence in support of the continuum was found in her review of eleven patients with deep or phonological dyslexia in whom she found a predictable succession of symptoms. She placed great emphasis on the order in which reading symptoms emerged (poor nonword reading first, then visual errors, then noun > functor, then noun > verb, concrete > abstract, and finally, semantic errors) and suggested that the continuum hypothesis was supported by this pattern of symptoms.<ref name=":0" />
===Connectionist model===
[[File:Connectionist model of deep dyslexia.png|thumb|right|300px|Deep dyslexics have sufficient activation of a written word's features; but, this activation decays quickly, leading to errors in speech output.]] The "connectionist model" suggests that the phonological and semantic features of a word are [[Spreading activation|activated]], but this activation decays at a rate too quick for cognitive processing- thus, errors in speech output are produced as a result of this fading activation.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Buchanan" /> This hypothesis explains the broad symptom-complex of deep dyslexics without resorting to a multiple loci damage approach as seen in other models.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Buchanan" /> It eliminates the need to attribute a specific locus of damage to each symptom of deep dylsexia, and instead states that all symptoms are due to decay of a large activation area.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Buchanan" />
=== Distributed attractor networks === Plaut and Shallice have hypothesized that units in the brain interact in such a way that semantic features form stable attractors in the space of all possible representations of words. These unit interactions correspond to particular attractor patterns, and if the particular attractor pattern is activated, the network remains in that pattern. However, they hypothesize that when the pattern is distorted, there is a pull on the pattern, and it gravitates toward the correct pattern, almost as if this semantic space is filled with basins, where if one point on the pattern falls to the edge of the basin, it will still gravitate toward the middle. If you lesion this area, the neurons die and the basins change their shape. When this happens, you may now have the same distorted starting pattern that will end up in a neighboring basin, which is a semantically related area, but not the correct one, and this would account for deep dyslexic patients to incorrectly identify "river" as "ocean". Lesions that occur early in the network change the basins that send different semantic words to different areas of the network, whereas if they occur later, the words will be much closer semantically. This may account for severity of the deficit in individual patients.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Plaut|first=D.C.|date=|year=1995|title=Double Dissociation Without Modularity: Evidence from Connectionist Neuropsychology|url=|journal=Journal of Clinical and Experimental Neuropsychology|volume=17|issue=2|pages=291–321|doi=10.1080/01688639508405124|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Failure of inhibition hypothesis===
The "failure of inhibition hypothesis" states that the presentation of a target word activates [[semantic memory]] of that word, along with memory for other words that are semantically related.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> For example, the target word "dog" may activate "bark", "cat", "squirrel", "ball", "fetch". Deep dyslexic patients are unable to inhibit the other related words, so they are likely to substitute one of these words for the target word in speech production (explicit output).<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> This hypothesis contradicts the belief of other researchers that the deficits seen in deep dyslexics are due to [[Mental process|processing]] problems.
Researchers believe that "failure of inhibition" has no effect on [[Implicit learning|implicit]] processing, but instead is the cause of impairments in the explicit task of speech production.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> They believe that explicit characteristics of reading involve only the conscious production of speech (reading).<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> Information about written words is internalized without awareness (implicitly); the ability to access this information and process it into words that can be read or spoken is an explicit process. Implicit knowledge involves [[phonological awareness]], understanding of the [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphology]], and a semantic understanding of written words.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> This implicit aspect of reading may be completely intact, and yet reading errors can still occur through defects in explicit output, or production.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> Researchers have studied the dissociation of implicit and explicit processes to thus unravel the underlying deficiencies in deep dyslexia. Studies in support of "failure of inhibition" show intact implicit processing of deep dyslexics.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> For instance, studies have shown deep dyslexics that are equally fast in a [[lexical decision task]] with a rhyming pair of words (book-took) in comparison to a non-rhyming pair of words (bough-tough), indicating that the patients are able to use implicit phonological knowledge and [[phonics]] to process the words.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> Additionally, they are faster in a lexical decision task with words that sound like they are spelled (couch, pouch) than they are with words that do not sound like they are spelled (touch), again showing that patients are using phonology.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> These data show that implicit processing is in fact occurring in deep dyslexic patients. Thus, some researchers believe that the impairments present in deep dyslexics are only in explicit phonological output (i.e., reading aloud).<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> They believe that the problems of deep dyslexics are due to production errors, and that deep dyslexics have normal phonological processing at the implicit level.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> This is supported by the fact that deep dyslexia is often present in patients suffering from production errors resulting from [[Expressive aphasia]].<ref name= "Lambon" />
Riley and Thompson expanded on this theory in 2010. Previous studies had shown that typical in patients with deep dyslexia, typical members of a semantic category (like "robin" in the category of "birds") are processed faster than atypical members of the same category (like "ostrich"), known as the semantic typicality effect. According to their research, this typicality effect may indicate an inability to efficiently select a correct lexical-semantic representation. They suggest that selection inhibition becomes impaired beginning at the level of semantics rather than the later levels of production like the original failure of inhibition hypothesis suggests.<ref name="Riley" />
===Dual route model===
[[File:Dual route model and deep dyslexia diagram.svg|thumb|right|300px|Deep dyslexia can affect both pathways in the dual-route hypothesis of reading.]] {{main article|Dual-route hypothesis to reading aloud}} The "Morton and Patterson (dual route) model" is based upon the [[Dual-route hypothesis to reading aloud|dual route hypothesis of reading]]. It proposes that the occurrence of semantic errors alongside an inability to read non-words aloud must be due to multiple loci of damage within this dual-route model.<ref name= "Colangelo" /> Because a deep dyslexic cannot read aloud non-words, a disruption in the [[Phonology|phonological]] process is assumed, forcing reading to proceed through the semantic route.<ref name= "Colangelo" /> However, deep dyslexics also produce semantic errors while reading, alluding to damage in this pathway as well.<ref name= "Colangelo" /> Other researchers refer to the phonological and semantic route as "modules".<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /><ref name= "Orden" /> They believe that patients have a partially functioning [[Lexicon|lexical]] module and a completely deficient nonlexical module.<ref name= "Orden" /> The lexical module is analogous to the semantic route in the dual route model and relies on lexical memory, or the memory for words, to name words.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /><ref name= "Orden" /> In using the lexical module, an individual accesses a "mental dictionary" of words. The nonlexical module is comparable to the phonological route and uses knowledge of spelling and [[grapheme]]s to create [[phoneme]]s to name words and nonwords.<ref name= "Orden" /> The absent nonlexical module in deep dyslexics explains why patients cannot name nonwords.<ref name= "Orden" />
===Right and left hemisphere hypotheses=== [[File:HearReadBrain.png|thumb|Activation areas in the left hemisphere when hearing or reading a word. The "left-hemisphere hypothesis", supports the idea of a damaged left hemisphere-based reading system.]]
Normal reading is typically a function of a left [[Lateralization of brain function|hemisphere-based system]].<ref name= "Coslett" /> The right [[Cerebral hemisphere|hemisphere]] plays a minimal role in reading.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Shallice" /> One hypothesis, the "left hemisphere hypothesis", supports the idea of a damaged left hemisphere-based reading system associated with deep dyslexia.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Coltheart">{{cite journal|last=Coltheart|first=Max|title=Deep Dyslexia Is Right-Hemisphere Reading|journal=Brain and Language|year=2000|volume=71|issue=2|pages=299–309|doi=10.1006/brln.1999.2183}}</ref><ref name= "Salmelin">{{cite journal|last=Salmelin|first=R|author2=Helenius, P |author3=Service, E |title=Neurophysiology of fluent and impaired reading: a magnetoencephalographic approach.|journal=Journal of Clinical Neurophysiology|year=2000|volume=17|issue=2|pages=163–74|pmid=10831107|doi=10.1097/00004691-200003000-00005}}</ref> Deep dyslexics may be attempting to use this damaged left hemisphere, resulting in severe reading deficits.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Coltheart" /><ref name= "Salmelin" /><ref>{{cite book|last=Warrington|first=Rosaleen A. McCarthy, Elizabeth K.|title=Cognitive neuropsychology : a clinical introduction|year=1990|publisher=Academic Press|location=San Diego|isbn=0124818463|edition=[7. Nachdr.]}}</ref> On the other hand, the "right hemisphere hypothesis" states that deep dyslexics attempt to read using a completely different reading system.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Shallice" /><ref name= "Coltheart" /> According to this hypothesis, they are using the right hemisphere for [[Orthography|orthographic]] and semantic processing, but given that this system does not usually play a role in reading, deep dyslexics have many reading disabilities.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Coltheart" /> Strong support for this hypothesis comes from studies of [[split-brain]] patients who use the right hemisphere for reading. These patients makes semantic errors similar to those seen with deep dyslexia.<ref>{{cite book|last=Shallice|first=Tim|title=From neuropsychology to mental structure|year=1988|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page= 112|location=Cambridge [England]|isbn=0521308747|edition=Reprint.}}</ref> Numerous studies have shown that the right hemisphere ''can'' contribute to reading when a patient's left hemisphere is damaged.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Shallice" /> Brain imaging studies, performed both on deep dyslexics and in other patients with left hemisphere injury, have shown that the damaged left hemisphere is still playing a role in reading.<ref name= "Coltheart" /><ref name= "Salmelin" /> However, the imaging has also shown that areas of the right hemisphere are also active during reading.<ref name= "Coltheart" /><ref name= "Salmelin" /> Thus, it currently appears that there is greater support in favor of the right-hemisphere hypothesis.<ref name = "Coltheart" />
==Treatment== There have been many different studies done in an attempt to treat deep dyslexics, all which have been met with varying success. One method that has been frequently used is to teach patients to sound out words using grapheme-to-phoneme correspondence rules (for example, using single letter graphemes such as the letter 'B" to link with larger words such as "Baby", allowing for association of phonemes).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Friedman|first=Rhonda B.|author2=Lott, Susan Nitzberg|title=Successful blending in a phonological reading treatment for deep alexia|journal=Aphasiology|year=2002|volume=16|issue=3|pages=355–372|doi=10.1080/02687040143000627}}</ref> Such methods are known as "non-lexically based reading treatments". Other studies have looked at attempting to repair the semantic-lexical route, known as "lexically based treatment".<ref name= "Rilling">{{cite journal|last=Stadie|first=Nicole|author2=Rilling, Eva|title=Evaluation of lexically and nonlexically based reading treatment in a deep dyslexic|journal=Cognitive Neuropsychology|year=2006|volume=23|issue=4|pages=643–672|doi=10.1080/02643290500538364}}<!--|accessdate=16 March 2013--></ref> Regardless of the methodology, treatment studies with deep dyslexics are difficult because much of the information regarding this disability is still heavily debated.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} Treatment options may be successful on repairing one route of reading but not another, and success for one patient may not translate to success in another.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
<!-- Navigation boxes -->
{{Speech and voice symptoms and signs}} {{dyslexia}}

revision.text:
'''Foreign language anxiety''', or '''xenoglossophobia''', is the feeling of [[wikt:unease|unease]], [[worry]], [[anxiety|nervousness]] and [[apprehension (fear)|apprehension]] experienced in learning or using a [[second language|second]] or [[foreign language]]. The feelings may stem from any second language context whether it is associated with the productive skills of [[speech|speaking]] and [[writing]] or the receptive skills of [[reading (process)|reading]] and listening.<ref name="MacIntyre">{{cite journal |last=MacIntyre |first=P. D. |last2=Gardner |first2=R. C. |year=1994 |title=The subtle effects of language anxiety on cognitive processing in the second language |journal=[[Language Learning (journal)|Language Learning]] |volume=44 |issue= |pages=283–305 |doi= 10.1111/j.1467-1770.1994.tb01103.x}}</ref>
Foreign language anxiety is a form of what [[psychologist]]s describe as a ''specific anxiety reaction''.<ref name="Horwitz 125–132">{{Cite journal|last=Horwitz|first=Elaine K.|last2=Horwitz|first2=Michael B.|last3=Cope|first3=Joann|date=1986-06-01|title=Foreign Language Classroom Anxiety|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1540-4781.1986.tb05256.x/abstract|journal=The Modern Language Journal|language=en|volume=70|issue=2|pages=125–132|doi=10.1111/j.1540-4781.1986.tb05256.x|issn=1540-4781}}</ref> Some individuals are more predisposed to [[anxiety]] than others and may feel anxious in a wide variety of situations. Foreign language anxiety, however, is situation-specific and so it can also affect individuals who are not characteristically anxious in other situations.
==Causes== {{expert needed|the subject, as much of the article is largely incoherent|date=July 2017}} Although all aspects of using and learning a foreign language can cause anxiety, both listening and speaking are regularly cited as the most anxiety provoking of foreign language activities.<ref name="MacIntyre" /><ref name="Horwitz">{{cite journal |last=Horwirz |first=E. K. |last2=Horwitz |first2=M. B. |last3=Cope |first3=J. |year=1986 |title=Foreign Language Classroom Anxiety |journal=The Modern Language Journal |volume=70 |issue=ii |pages= |ref=harv |doi=10.2307/327317}}</ref> Foreign language anxiety is usually studied and seen in a language classroom situation. It has been argued that language learning is a "profoundly unsettling psychological proposition"<ref name="Horwitz 125–132"/> as it jeopardizes an individual's self-understanding and perspective.<ref name="Horwitz 125–132"/> Three theories of anxiety have been developed from internal appraisal, then more situational in learning language and contextual situation{{clarify|date=July 2017}}:<ref name=":0" /> * self-efficacy and appraisal anxiety * state, trait, situational anxiety * situational anxiety in a classroom situation Potential negative events that people cannot see or handle with their ability{{clarify|date=July 2017}} often leads to anxiety. Also, if individuals are highly anxious, that kind of habitualised reactions{{clarify|date=July 2017}} may cause those who have experienced many threatening situations in the past to be more likely perceive future situations as threatening. As well, if their anxiety are traits rather than states, self-efficacy must result from past successes, vicarious experiences and social persuasion.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Pappamihiel|first1=N. Eleni|title=English as a Second Language Students and English Language Anxiety: Issues in the Mainstream Classroom|journal=Research in the Teaching of English|date=1 January 2002|volume=36|issue=3|pages=327–355|jstor=40171530}}</ref>
''Self-efficacy'' is one's own confidence that he or she would be able to handle to achieve intended goals. ''State, trait, situational anxiety'' refers to those who have gotten traumatised a lot in the past being more likely to perceive the future situations as treating too. Also, specifically in an ESL classroom, students learning a foreign language out of their country are very vulnerable to high levels of anxiety about language learning, which leads them to being less likely to get encouraged by others because of lacking vicarious experience and social persuasions.<ref name=":0" />
More specifically, foreign language anxiety is seen in a language classroom. As such, the causes of foreign language anxiety have been broadly separated into three main components: [[communication apprehension]], [[test anxiety]] and [[fear of negative evaluation]].<ref name="Horwitz" /> Communication apprehension is the anxiety experienced in speaking or listening to other individuals. Test-anxiety is a form of [[performance anxiety]] associated with the fear of doing badly or failing altogether. Fear of negative evaluation is the anxiety associated with the learner's perception of how other onlookers (instructors, classmates or others) may negatively view their language ability.
Sparks and Ganschow<ref name="SparksGanschow1991">{{cite journal|last1=Sparks|first1=Richard L.|last2=Ganschow|first2=Leonore|title=Foreign Language Learning Differences: Affective or Native Language Aptitude Differences?|journal=The Modern Language Journal|volume=75|issue=1|year=1991|pages=3–16|issn=0026-7902|doi=10.1111/j.1540-4781.1991.tb01076.x}}</ref> asked a question, which drew attention to the fact that anxiety could be a cause of poor language learning or a result of poor language learning. If a student is unable to study as required before writing a language examination, the student could experience test anxiety. Context anxiety could be viewed as a result. In contrast, anxiety becomes a cause of poor language learning when it was due to anxiety that student is unable to adequately learn the target language.
There can be various physical causes of anxiety, such as hormone levels, but the underlying causes of excessive anxiety while learning are fear<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shahsavari|first1=Mahmood|title=Relationship between anxiety and achievement motivation among male and female students|journal=Journal of American Science|date=2012|volume=8|issue=11|pages=329–332|url=http://www.jofamericanscience.org/journals/am-sci/am0811/048_11656am0811_329_332.pdf|accessdate=23 January 2017|publisher=AmericanScience.org / Marsland Press|issn=2375-7264<!-- print: 1545-1003 -->}}</ref> and a lack of confidence. Lack of confidence itself can come from various causes. One reason can be the teaching approach<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Riasati|first1=Mohammad Javad|title=Language Learning Anxiety from EFL Learners' Perspective|journal=Middle-East Journal of Scientific Research|date=2011|volume=7|issue=6|pages=907–914|url=http://idosi.org/mejsr/mejsr7(6)11/13.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826001617/http://idosi.org/mejsr/mejsr7(6)11/13.pdf|archive-date=26 August 2016|deadurl=no|accessdate=23 January 2017|publisher=IDOSI Publications|issn=1990-9233}}</ref> used.
Furthermore, foreign language anxiety roots in three psychological challenges: * performance difficulty * threat * identity conflict Those psychological states thus have task-performance and identity dimensions. People tend to act or speak in a way that would be judged appropriate to the other people native to the foreign culture, but the behaviour that individuals are producing grapples with ingrained values and behaviours. Emotions by the psychological challenges has something to do with attempting to switch codes in an interactive encounter.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal|last1=Molinsky|first1=Andrew|title=Cross-Cultural Code-Switching: The Psychological Challenges of Adapting Behavior in Foreign Cultural Interactions|journal=The Academy of Management Review|date=1 January 2007|volume=32|issue=2|pages=622–640|doi=10.2307/20159318|jstor=20159318}}</ref>
==Effects== The effects of foreign language anxiety are particularly evident in the foreign language classroom, and anxiety is a strong indicator of academic performance. Anxiety is found to have a detrimental effect on students' [[confidence]], [[self-esteem]] and level of participation.<ref name="Horwitz" />
Anxious learners suffer detrimental effects during spontaneous speaking activities in performance, affective reactions and their overall attitudes towards learning their target second language<ref name="Phillips">{{cite journal |last=Phillips |first=E. M. |year=1992 |title=The effects of language anxiety on students' oral test performance and attitudes |journal=The Modern Language Journal |volume=76 |issue= 1|pages=14-26 |doi=10.1111/j.1540-4781.1992.tb02573.x}}</ref>. Furthermore, they may lack confidence, be less able to self-edit and identify language errors and more likely to employ [[avoidance coping|avoidance]] strategies such as skipping class.<ref name="Gregerson">{{cite journal |last=Gregerson |first=T. |year=2003 |title=To err is human: A reminder to teachers of language-anxious students |journal=Foreign Language Annals |volume=36 |issue=1 |pages=25–32 |doi= 10.1111/j.1944-9720.2003.tb01929.x}}</ref> Anxious students also forget previously learned material, volunteer answers less frequently and tend to be more passive in classroom activities than their less anxious counterparts.<ref name="Horwitz" /><ref name="Ely">{{cite journal |last=Ely |first=C. M. |year=1986 |title=An analysis of discomfort, risk-taking, sociability, and motivation in the L2 classroom |journal=Language Learning |volume=36 |issue= |pages=1–25 |doi= 10.1111/j.1467-1770.1986.tb00366.x}}</ref>
The effects of foreign language anxiety also extend outside the second language classroom. A high level of foreign language anxiety may also correspond with communication apprehension, causing individuals to be quieter and less willing to communicate.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Liu |first=M. |last2=Jackson |first2=J. |year=2008 |title=An exploration of Chinese EFL learners’ Unwillingness to Communicate and Foreign Language Anxiety |journal=The Modern Language Journal |volume=92 |issue=i |pages=71–86 |doi= 10.1111/j.1540-4781.2008.00687.x}}</ref> People who exhibit this kind of communication [[reticence]] can also sometimes be perceived as less trustworthy, less competent, less socially and physically attractive, tenser, less composed and less dominant than their less reticent counterparts.
=== Cross-cultural code-switching === The effects of these negative emotions may also lead to '''cross-cultural code-switching''', in which bilingual people alter a language to their other language{{clarify|date=July 2017}} through their interactions with other bilinguals. Unlike linguistic [[code-switching]], cross-cultural code-switching is the socio-linguistic phenomenon of changing culturally-ingrained behaviors in a foreign situation.<ref name=":1" /> Although cross-cultural code-switching possibly results from both positive and negative emotions, negative emotions are more common and more likely to affect the way a bilingual person speaks. Negative emotions include embarrassment, performance anxiety, guilt, distress and anxiety.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Molinsky|first=Andrew|date=2007-01-01|title=Cross-Cultural Code-Switching: The Psychological Challenges of Adapting Behavior in Foreign Cultural Interactions|jstor=20159318|journal=The Academy of Management Review|volume=32|issue=2|pages=622–640|doi=10.2307/20159318}}</ref> "Molinsky identifies three psychological states that appraise under the influence of emotions while code-switching. These are: "experienced performance difficulty, face threat and identity conflict—all of which mediate the relationship between personal and contextual variables and the negative and positive emotions an individual experiences while code-switching".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.diplom.de/document/228636|title=Diplom.de - Cross-cultural Code Switching and Application|website=www.diplom.de|language=de|access-date=2017-10-26}}</ref>
There are three types of cross-cultural code-switching:<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Titone|first=Renzo|date=1994-01-01|title=Some Italian Investigations of 'Code Switching' in Diglossic Settings: A Summary Report|jstor=30249052|journal=La Linguistique|volume=30|issue=2|pages=67–73}}</ref> * situational code-switching * conversational code-switching * borrowing This code-switching could be considered as an unconscious behavior because of its negative and usually threatening situations.{{clarify|date=July 2017}} In that sense, although code-switching results from foreign language anxiety, it is more often caused by external circumstances than by internal mental change.{{clarify|date=July 2017}}<ref name=":2" />
==Measures== A number of tools have been developed to investigate the level of foreign language anxiety experienced by language learners.
The Foreign Language Classroom Anxiety Scale (FLCAS)<ref name="Horwitz" /> is a 33-question, 5-point [[Likert scale]] survey, which is widely used in research studies. It investigates participants' communication apprehension, test-anxiety and fear of negative evaluation and focuses on speaking in a classroom context. It has been translated and used in several languages, including [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Chinese language|Chinese]].
Following the success of the Foreign Language Classroom Anxiety scale, similar instruments have been devised for measuring Foreign Language Reading Anxiety (FLRAS),<ref>{{cite journal |last=Saito |first=Y. |last2=Horwitz |first2=E. K. |last3=Garza |first3=T. J. |year=1999 |title=Foreign Language Reading Anxiety |journal=The Modern Language Journal |volume=83 |issue= |pages=202–218 |doi= 10.1111/0026-7902.00016}}</ref> Foreign Language Listening Anxiety (FLLAS) and Second Language Writing Apprehension (SLWAT).<ref>{{cite journal |last=Cheng |first=Y. S. |last2=Horwitz |first2=E. K. |last3=Shallert |first3=D. L. |year=1999 |title=Language anxiety: Differentiating writing and speaking components |journal=Language Learning |volume=49 |issue= |pages=417–446 |doi= 10.1111/0023-8333.00095}}</ref>
== Issues and area of research == In the 1990s, the challenge was a clear categorisation of grammatical or sociolinguistic constraints on code-switching caused by foreign language anxiety and to determine how bilinguals produce different code-mixed patterns. In fact, previously, most researches focused more upon syntactic aspects on code-switching; in other words, psychological elements were completely ignored.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Myers-Scotton|first1=Carol|title=Common and Uncommon Ground: Social and Structural Factors in Codeswitching|journal=Language in Society|date=1 January 1993|volume=22|issue=4|pages=475–503|jstor=4168471|doi=10.1017/s0047404500017449}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite journal |last=Lin |first=G. H. C. |year=2009 |title=An exploration into foreign language writing anxiety from Taiwanese university students’ perspectives |conference=2009 NCUE Fourth Annual Conference on Language Teaching, Literature, Linguistics, Translation, and Interpretation |location=National Changhua University of Education, Department of English, Taiwan, ROC, |pages=307–318 |url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/44/f3/66.pdf }} *{{cite journal |last=Lin |first=G. H. C. |year=2008 |title=Pedagogies proving Krashen’s theory of affective filter |journal=Hwa Kang Journal of English Language & Literature |volume=14 |issue= |pages=113–131 |id=ERIC Collection as ED503681 |url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/42/c1/92.pdf }}
{{SLA topics}}
